_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM-CalARP program.



This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                | Process Chemical                | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration         Anhydrous Ammonia                 12,000





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The CalARP Program developed for this facility is designed to prevent the occurrence of, or minimize the consequences of, catastrophic releases by stating and implementing our policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in design, construction, start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance, and the other matters addressed in the CalARP Program regulation and the OSHA PSM Standard.  This comprehensive program has been developed to enable all those who may be affected to be able to identify and understand the hazards posed by the ammonia refrigeration process.



Our Program calls for maximum employee participation and includes all elements of the employee participation provisions of the regulation.  This Program document, as well as the other documents and reports that are created pursuant to this Program, are made accessible to our employees and to other affected persons in accordance with applicable requirements and the provisions of the CalARP Program.  See Policy Statement for the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program at the end of Chapter 1 (Overview) of

the program manual.



Emergency response measures have been developed and implemented for proper and safe evacuation and notifications to outside emergency responders.  These measures reflect the established policies of this facility for ensuring the health and safety of all employees and those who may be on site or in the area in the event of an accidental release of ammonia.



This CalARP Program is regularly reviewed and updated as required, and whenever necessary to reflect new or modified tasks and procedures.  Dot Foods corporate personnel ensure that safety and environmental policies are implemented at local Dot Foods facilities by conducting periodic compliance inspections.

 

THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The only regulated substance at this facility subject to the Accidental Release Prevention programs or the Process Safety Management Standards is anhydrous ammonia in the refrigeration system.



Facility Description



Dot Foods, Inc. is the largest food re-distributor service in the United States.  The facility warehouses food service products for distribution, along with ten (10) additional distribution facilities throughout the United States.  The corporate office is located in Mt. Sterling, Illinois.



The Dot Foods facility in Modesto, California is located at 2200 Nickerson Drive, east of Crows Landing Road at the intersection of Nickerson Drive and Jayann Way.



The area around the facility is comprised of industrial facilities, commercial establishments, agricultural areas, and residential neighborhoods.  The facility is bordered by industrial facilities on the east and commercial establishments to the south.  Empty fields lie to the west and north of the plant.



The facility is also located directly adjacent to, and west of the Union Pacific railroad tracks and approximately ? mile southwest of State Highway 99.  The Tuolumne River lies slightly more than one mile northwest of the facility.



The facility maint

ains approximately 65 full time employees on site.  The plant operates seven (7) days per week, with two (2) ten-hour shifts per day.  



The plant is comprised of a main office, ammonia refrigeration Machine Room, two (2) frozen warehouses, one (1) refrigerated warehouse, one (1) refrigerated dock, one (1) dry dock, (1) dry warehouse, maintenance shop, truck garage, trailer parking, employee parking, and a guard shack.  The facility is fenced along the entire perimeter with a main entrance on the south side for employees and visitors.  The truck entrance is located at the southwest corner of the facility.



The Machine Room for the refrigeration system is located on the west side adjacent to the Electrical Room and Maintenance Office.  The Emergency Evacuation Assembly Areas for toxic releases are located at the truck garage break area and the main Break Room.



Process Description



Dot Foods operates one (1) refrigeration system which uses approximately 12,000 lbs. anhydrous ammonia as the heat transfer fluid.   The refrigeration system is used to maintain cooling and freezing for warehouse products.  The refrigeration system began operation in March 1998 and was designed and constructed under the applicable fire and mechanical codes.



The system is a single-stage, multi-suction, economized mechanical refrigeration system that utilizes recirculated liquid feed to the evaporator coils.  Cooling is required for the 35?F Refrigerated Dock and Refrigerated Warehouse and for the -2?F Freezer Warehouse.  There are two rooms adjacent to the Freezer Warehouse, each with two (2) evaporator coil units that can be converted to/from refrigerated or frozen space.  The anhydrous ammonia also serves as a heat exchange medium for the under-floor glycol heating system.



System components are connected with steel piping approved for ammonia refrigeration service and the system is controlled by the programmable logic controller (PLC), the microprocessors at the screw compre

ssors, safety switches, detection, and control valves.



The compressors, pressure vessels, pumps, gauge board, and purger are located in the Machine Room; the condenser and heat exchanger are located on the Machine Room roof; the fire control box and the ammonia diffusion tank are located outside the Machine Room; and, the evaporators are located in their respective cooling and freezing areas.



 

The Primary System Components include the following:



QUANTITY    DESCRIPTION

4    Screw Compressor Packages

1    Evaporative Condenser

1    High-Pressure Receiver

1    Thermosyphon Receiver

1    High Temperature Recirculator

1    Low Temperature Recirculator

4    Ammonia Pumps

2    Oil Pots

1    Glycol Heat Exchanger

1    Auto Purger

4    Dock Evaporators

4    Freezer Evaporators

4    Convertible Cooler / Freezer Evaporators



System Operation



The Evaporative Condenser drains high-pressure liquid to the Thermosiphon Receiver for screw compressor oil cooling.  The Thermosiphon Receiver also supplies high-pressure liquid ammonia to the High Pressure Receiver, which then supplies liquid to the High Temperature Recirculator for recirculated liquid cooling to the Evaporator coils.  As the liquid ammonia leaves the High Temperature Recirculator, an expansion valve reduces the temperature and pressure of the liquid to the coils to maintain a pre-determined pressure.



Liquid ammonia from the High Temperature Recirculator is supplied to the Low Temperature Recirculator through an expansion valve, which maintains the vessel at a lower pressure.  Liquid from the High Temperature Recirculator is pumped to the Truck Dock Evaporators and optionally to the Convertible Evaporators when high temperature cooling is desired in that space.   Liquid from the Low Temperature Recirculator is pumped to the Freezer Evaporators and optionally to the Convertible Evaporators when low temperature cooling is desired in that space.



Prior to entering the Evaporator coils, the ammonia expands and flashes to saturation

temperature as the pressure is reduced through the respective expansion valves.  The resulting low-pressure liquid ammonia absorbs heat from the space as the liquid ammonia evaporates in the coils.



Saturated ammonia vapor is returned from the Truck Dock coils to the High Temperature Recirculator and from the Freezer coils to the Low Temperature Recirculator where the vapor is separated from the liquid.  Constant pressure to the High Temperature Recirculator is maintained with backpressure regulating valves, located before the economizer ports of the compressors.  The Low Temperature Recirculator pressure is maintained by the main suction pressure of the compressors.



High temperature vapor from the High Temperature Recirculator provides economized suction to the compressors and low temperature vapor from the Low Temperature Recirculator provides low temperature suction.  High-pressure, high-temperature ammonia vapor discharge from the compressors provides hot gas for the glycol heat exchanger, hot gas defrost for the Evaporator coils, and high stage discharge to the Evaporative Condenser.  The heat of compression in the compressor discharge is removed in the Evaporative Condenser.  Liquid discharge from the glycol heat exchanger is returned to the thermosyphon supply line to the compressors.



An Autopurger periodically removes noncondensibles from the system.  The fire control box outside the Machine Room is operated by fire department personnel in the event of emergency.  The Ammonia Diffusion Tank is maintained full of water to absorb a system overpressure release from the vessel pressure relief valves.  Emergency E-stop switches are located outside each Machine Room entrance for emergency shutdown.  Ammonia sensors in the Machine Room and cooling/freezing rooms trigger audible/visual notifications, liquid flow shutdown, purge ventilation activation, and equipment shutdown at prescribed levels.



The operation staff consists of the Maintenance Supervisor

uired by the OSHA PSM Standard and the Program 3 requirements of the CalARP regulation.  Specifically, the elements of the release prevention program are:



1.    Employee Participation Program

2.    Process Safety Information

3.    Process Hazard Analysis

4.    Operating Procedures

5.    Training

6.    Contractors

7.    Pre-Startup Safety Review

8.    Mechanical Integrity

9.    Hot Work

10.    Management of Change

11.    Incident Investigation

12.    Emergency Planning & Response

13.    Compliance Audit

14.    Trade Secrets



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no accidental releases of ammonia at the Dot Foods facility in the past five years that are subject to the CalARP or EPA Accidental Release Prevention Program reporting requirements.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Dot Foods maintains an Emergency Planning & Response Program (Emergency Action Plan) as described in the CalARP Program manual.  As a facility that will not respond to uncontrolled releases, the emergency response measures primarily include the safe evacuation of all personnel and notification to outside emergency responders.  Incidental releases that do not pose an imminent safety hazard may be abated by employees or contractors who are trained to provide such a response, are wearing the appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE), are authorized by Dot Foods to perform such activities, and are in the area of the release at the time of discovery.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



1.    Minor modification to the Standard Operating Procedures.

2.    Minor modifications to the Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&ID).

3.      Review water treatment program.

4.      Add a stairway to the roof.
